message_1:
Two hunters are out in the forest searching for stags. Each hunter can choose to cooperate with the other and hunt a stag together or hunt alone and catch a hare. If one hunter chooses to hunt stag and the other chooses to hunt hare, the hunter who hunts stag will get nothing, and the hunter who hunts hare will get one point. If both hunters choose to hunt hare, both will get one point each. However, if both hunters choose to hunt stag, both will get two points each. 

Suppose the payoffs for each outcome are as follows:

- Both hunters hunt hare: 1 point each
- One hunter hunts stag, while the other hunts hare: 0 points for the hunter who hunts stag, and 1 point for the hunter who hunts hare
- Both hunters hunt stag: 2 points each

What would be the Nash equilibrium of this game?
message_2:
In this game, there are two Nash equilibria:

1. Both hunters choose to hunt hare (Hare, Hare): In this case, each hunter gets 1 point. If either hunter deviates and hunts stag, they will get 0 points while the other hunter still gets 1 point. So, neither hunter has an incentive to deviate from hunting hare.

2. Both hunters choose to hunt stag (Stag, Stag): In this case, each hunter gets 2 points. If either hunter deviates and hunts hare, their payoff will decrease to 1 point while the other hunter's payoff will decrease to 0 points. So, neither hunter has an incentive to deviate from hunting stag.

Thus, the Nash equilibria of this game are (Hare, Hare) and (Stag, Stag).
